Hi Daniel,

I was just recently informed about the no hidden nodes bug and =
I was going to release an updated version, but then the issue of the optimi=
zation was brought up, so I decided to wait until I decided what to do with=
 that before I released anything.  I apologize for that.

As for getting di=
fferent results when reloading genomes, the most common reason for this err=
or have been conflicting or missing params.txt files, as Colin suggested.  =
The only other situations I've run into have been accidentally using differ=
ent substrates and recently when someone created their visualizer project t=
he references to SharpNeatLib got messed up.  That last one seemed like a s=
pecial case, but you can test for it by using this code outline to load and=
 test a genome in your main class.  You can also use MessageBox.show() in y=
our visualization project with this code to see if that produces the correc=
t fitness value.

NeatGenome testGenome;		
try
{
	XmlDocument XML =3D new X=
mlDocument();
	XML.Load(testGenomeFilename);
	testGenome =3D XmlNeatGenomeR=
eaderStatic.Read(XML);
}
catch (Exception e)
{
	System.Console.WriteLine("P=
roblem loading genome: \n" + e.Message);
	System.Environment.Exit(1);
}
You=
rNetworkEvaluator eval =3D new YourNetworkEvaluator();
double fitness =3D e=
val.networkEvaluate(testGenome.Decode());
System.Console.WriteLine("Fitness=
:  " + fitness);

Failing that, your method #3 was correct.  The process fo=
r loading a genome is:

1. Setup experimental parameters.
2. Load the XML i=
nto a genome.
3. Decode the genome into a CPPN (as an INetwork)
4. Use your=
 Substrate to query the CPPN, producing a NeatGenome or INetwork that will =
be used in the domain.

So that seems OK.  You can try dumping the INetwork=
s produced by the substrate (i.e. the actual ANNs being evaluated) of the b=
est genomes to XML and compare those to the networks you get from loading t=
he genomes back in during visualization and putting them through the substr=
ate.  If they are the same, perhaps some of the domain parameters are diffe=
rent?  If they are different, check that the substrates and related paramet=
ers are the same (using YourNetworkEvalutor.substrate can help with this is=
sue).

Let me know how things go,
David D'Ambrosio

--- In neat@yahoogroups=
.com, "Daniel" <daniel_kuppitz@...> wrote:
>
> No, I use the same params.tx=
t in each project. But what I found out now is that I've mixed up the const=
ructor parameters; instead of passing the 9 as the output neuron parameter =
I passed it as the hidden neuron parameter. After changing that I got one O=
utOfMemoryException after another. There's a bug in Substrate.cs in line 13=
3:
> 
> for (uint outputs =3D 0; outputs < outputCount; output++, coordinat=
es[2] +=3D outputDelta)
> 
> should be
> 
> for (uint outputs =3D 0; output=
s < outputCount; outputs++, coordinates[2] +=3D outputDelta)
> 
> I'm quite=
 sure that I never touched this line of code. Unfortunately my initial prob=
lem is back - the visualizer produces different outputs. I surely overlook =
something, I have just no idea what it is.
> 
> Cheers,
> Daniel
> 
> --- I=
n neat@yahoogroups.com, Colin Green <colin.green1@> wrote:
> >
> > 2009/11/=
29 Daniel <daniel_kuppitz@>
> > >
> > > The confusion deepens. I've changed=
 the activation function to BipolarsSigmoid and guess what: Same input resu=
lts in the same
> > > output now.
> > > I really don't understand it, but i=
t's great to have a visualizer now :)
> > 
> > 
> > I wonder if the wrong p=
arameter or params.txt file is being read when
> > you're evolving the netw=
orks? So they might have been using
> > BipolarSigmoid all along?
> >
>
